topic_name: Directory: list of filenames and inodes. And iNode doesn't contain filename but everything else in its metadata!

questions.question: Why are filenames stored in directories rather than within the inode structure itself?
options: To allow multiple filenames (hard links) to reference the same inode
To save memory space since filenames are usually very short
To make file access faster by keeping inodes smaller
To prevent unauthorized users from seeing filenames
questions.explanation: Storing filenames in directories rather than inodes allows multiple directory entries to point to the same inode, enabling hard links where one file can have multiple names.

questions.question: When a file system needs to locate a file given its full path '/home/user/document.txt', what is the correct sequence of operations?
options: Search all inodes for the filename, then read the inode metadata
Parse the path and traverse directories, looking up each component to find the corresponding inode
Use the filename hash to directly calculate the inode number
Search the master file table for the complete path string
questions.explanation: The file system must parse the path components and traverse each directory level, using the directory's filename-to-inode mapping to eventually locate the target file's inode.

questions.question: What metadata would you expect to find in an inode but NOT in a directory entry?
options: The filename and file extension
File permissions, timestamps, and block pointers
The parent directory reference
The alphabetical sort order for the directory listing
questions.explanation: Inodes contain all file metadata except the filename - including permissions, timestamps, size, and pointers to data blocks. Directory entries only contain the filename-to-inode mapping.

questions.question: In what scenario would understanding the directory-inode relationship be most critical for a system administrator?
options: When optimizing file compression ratios
When recovering a corrupted file system where directory structures are damaged
When setting up network file sharing permissions
When choosing between different file formats for storage
questions.explanation: During file system recovery, understanding that directories map filenames to inodes is crucial because you might need to rebuild directory structures even when the actual file data (in inodes) is intact.

questions.question: If you delete a directory entry but the inode reference count is still greater than zero, what does this indicate about the file system state?
options: The file system is corrupted and needs immediate repair
The file still has other hard links pointing to the same inode
The file is currently open by a running process
The directory cache hasn't been updated yet
questions.explanation: When an inode's reference count remains above zero after deleting a directory entry, it means other directory entries (hard links) still point to that same inode, so the file data is preserved.
